Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Insight of broad concepts of Material Science.
I learned the basics of materials science (crystal structures, stress and strain, dislocations, failure, polymers, ceramics, metals, diffusion, and phase diagrams).
Materials Science in a vast swath of ways.
A general overview about materials and their properties. It is very important to have this basic knowledge as an engineer to be able to execute good designs.
Breadth (not depth) of materials science and processing
The class is a basic introduction to Materials Science.  It focused on metals but also briefly involved glasses, ceramics, and polymers.  There is some assumed chemistry knowledge.
The fundamentals and basics of understanding materials and their properties.

MENG285 taught a strong qualitative understanding of materials science and its relevance to modern mechanical engineering. The majority of the course time was spent studying the behavior of metals with brief insights into ceramics and polymers. Through mostly self-study because lectures tended to be unclear, I learned the fundamentals of mechanical properties, behavior, diffusion, failure, and more.
General understanding of the molecular explanations for why materials act the way they do and how to deal with it.
Insight into the physical processes behind the function and applications of materials

This course provides a broad overview of topics related to materials science. It's definitely a survey course, but each topic is interesting and it involves a mix of chemistry, physics, and other sciences.
knowledge of materials sciences.
In a broad sense, I learned about the relationships between structure and properties in materials.
This course really in an introduction, meaning that you'll get nothing past the absolute basics.
If a syllabus was posted online about the specific material we were going to learn throughout the semester, it would've helped to be able to know specifically what to study for the exams.

This course was pretty bad. Pset due dates and questions seemed to be improvised last minute. Lectures were organized, but the professor had confusing explanations. The class lectures were not focused or clear or particularly relevant to the problem sets.

Strengths are that it's very all-encompassing and wide-reaching. There's much to be taught, but those things are disparate and often times unintuitive and stem from empirical facts. Spending more time connecting ideas and making sure they're understood before moving on would be beneficial.

Strengths: absolutely nothing apart from some insights Jan gives about his research
Weaknesses: Boring lectures. Jan's teaching style is messy and confusing. He stutters and mumbles a lot and can not utter coherent sentences.
Lecture slides are messy and not very helpful unless you take notes of every single thing Jan says. Sometimes the slides are just a bunch of pictures with few words or literally PICTURES of the board !
No clear feedback, no homework solutions, no exam solutions. Absolutely nothing. The class is not that hard itself so you can kind of read the book and learn by yourself but don't rely on other things.

Strength: can be taken by anyone (no specific knowledge required); provides a great insight into everything about materials for those who are curious.
Weaknesses: 1. could have been organized better 2. does not really provide any hard/fundamental knowledge
The material is interesting and the textbook is very good, but the lectures can be disorganized and confusing.

Would have helped to facilitate learning if the answers keys to problem sets and exams had ever been released. A practice exam or something of that format also would have been useful. It was frustrating for many students that these were not made available.

For those with a genuine interest in materials science, this course provides a great introductory survey of relevant topics even if it requires self-study. The textbook is very well-written, though it doesn't always cover the subject matter we discuss in class. That said, homework problems are either quantitative and from the textbook or qualitative and discussed in lecture, so the course material never feels like a surprise. Professor Jan is super kind, funny, and genuinely enjoys the material, though his lectures and explanations always leave much to be desired. Unfortunately, the language barrier is a problem as he often struggles to pick the right words to clearly explain topics in English. The discussion section would sometimes be very helpful and otherwise not at all. The biggest drawback from this course is that NO grades are uploaded to canvas, problem sets are returned erratically, and no clarity about a student's performance in the class is present.

The psets aren't really super representative of the exams, or what we are expected to know, which was a little confusing. But if the purpose of them was to do a bit of an exposure to the math behind all of the important concepts without really wanting to focus energy on memorizing things and whatnot, then it accomplished its purpose. The lectures weren't the most clear sometimes when it came to the more complicated derivations and things like that, and even the TAs couldn't clarify sometimes, so if there would be a way to teach some of that stuff more clearly then that would be helpful. Having some pset questions that resembled things we would see on exams, or just the things that the course was focused on making sure we understood would be helpful. The sections with TAs were really helpful for keying in on things and going more in depth, and the textbook was also a really solid resource, so that was all good.
I did NOT like the partnered homework. I thought it hurt my grade and reduced the amount I learned.

I thought the material itself was very interesting and Prof. Schroers is very nice and funny. However, the course was a little disorganized and some of the lectures were a little hard to follow even if you paid attention closely.
Jan does an amazing job explaining the material, though at times it can feel slow.
the level of explanation during lecture could be improved upon.

I like the problem sets I thought they were a great difficulty level and covered all the useful applications that we needed to know. I would have preferred more application examples during lecture. It would also be great if there was a more professional looking and comprehensive online guide to G-curves for phase diagrams that was pretty confusing and the book nor the lectures were easy to learn from.
The lector didn't really know what he was doing. Judging by the expertise of the teaching fellows, though, I think the issue isn't with the course.
Terrible lectures, psets aren't too hard, pretty boring.

There was no effort put into the course in any way.  There is no attempt to make the class impressionable in any way.  This course needs a more structured syllabus.  I say that despite the fact that there was no syllabus in the first place.  The only strength of this course is its relative ease, which is still undermined by the fact that I never really knew what I needed to know because there was no clarity on that subject.

Yes I would recommend this class. It is a great introduction to how materials interact with the real world. I took this class at the same time as MENG 280 and they complement each other nicely as well.
Do not take this course. It is easier to learn from the textbook. However, Jan's research is interesting.
Yep, it's cool stuff and there are people there to help you.

Yes, still yes because you'll learn interesting stuff about materials but maybe by yourself when Jan's confusing lectures make you open a book and explore stuff but if you want good professors this is not for you.

I would recommend it if you are either set on MechE/materials science and are taking it as one of your required classes or lookin for a science credit that is outside of regular intro science classes. However, the topic is pretty specific.
Only if it is required by your major.

I would recommend this course to another student as an easier than average elective in the mechanical engineering major and for a science credit. For students that are comfortable with chemistry at the AP level or higher, this class will be very reasonable. Don't set expectations too high.

Yes! I thought it was fun, and the concepts were really cool and enlightening - one of those classes that makes you see the world differently because you understand one of the layers you usually take for granted. It also wasn't too much work, and the lectures were pretty good (though some may disagree with me). Was a relatively laid back class I would say, which is always refreshing to find at Yale. I looked forward to lectures and section every week.
Most people don't take this course unless they are an engineering major
It is a good, basic introduction to materials. It's a little boring, but if you gotta take it you gotta take it...
Take this class if you want to learn about a tangential topic to mechanical engineering that is fun. You will learn a decent amount if you put in the effort.
Jan's amazing so definitely take if you're at all interested in materials science!
yes i thought the material was very interesting.
A great elective for MENG majors! Materials science is really cool and applicable to lots of different fields.
Not really. Unless the lector gets better.

If you have to take it, you have to take it. Lectures were the most unengaging of my entire life. Be prepared to learn the material on your own. The material itself is pretty interesting so that's nice, but the lectures are pretty unproductive. Jan just lectures off slides he finds off the internet, don't expect to get anything from lecture.
No, unless you need a mechanical engineering gut elective.  UNDER ANY UNDER CIRCUMSTANCE NO.  This class is not interesting, the course is taught poorly, and it is a horrible waste of your time.
